activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#8397
activity.text:
We need to keep the range of values more liberal. We can't look at the majority use case and choose to not acknowledge the edge cases. 

We must keep the range more open.

The issue here is the UI component - slider. Athul doc is worried that if the allowed range is too wide, the slider becomes extended where the usable (commonly used) range will be a small section within the slider.

So my recommendation is:

- [ ] We keep the allowed range of input relaxed
- [ ] Reimagine input modality. slider is not very usable. Scroll or any other modality may be considered
- [ ] Athul doc also recommended to add fields for "modality of measuring BP" and if, IVBP, then "site of measurement"- filing this as separate issue.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#8397
activity.text:
We can add validation to make sure that systolic pressure is always greater than diastolic pressure

However, Systolic BP can go below 50 in heart attack patients nearing death and other extreme cases. so it is not wise to only allow values above 50. Same with diastolic BP.

I believe we need to increase the higher ceiling of both systolic and diastolic BP. 
A published in 1995 has recorded a maximum blood pressure of 370/360 mmHg.
I recommend we allow values between 0 to 400 for both systolic and diastobil BP

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#7962
activity.text:
The reason why we need to classify patient as "mild moderate critical" is for the obvious need to understand what degree of care is provided to patients admitted. Having a 4th category for "actively dying" is important to understand the number of patients admitted, where the goal for healthcare providers is not to treat the patient to recovery but to provide the patient care so the patient can have a comfortable death. 

Having this classification is patients in important to make sense of patient outcomes. Where ever you have higher % of actively dying patients, % of expired in outcome will also be high. 

Earlier we were using the term "comfort care" for the classification. However using comfort care is not correct here because it is a wider term that may include patients actively dying or other patients that may be suffering from a disease like a viral infection that may not have any active treatment options. Some of such patients may recover. Hence the definition is "comfort care" is too wide. "Actively dying" is defined very specifically as patients that are dying. 

For analytics we will have 5 categories 
Mild
Moderate
Critical
Comfort care
Actively dying.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#7798
activity.text:
@rithviknishad the ideal thing to do is to have 3 numbers captured for every patient/encounter.

MRD (Medicine records department) No. /Patient ID: This is 1 unique ID for a patient per facility. Every new facility the patient goes to, a new unique ID within the facility will be issued to the patient.

IP No.: everytime the patient gets admitted, a unique IP number for the facility will be assigned to that encounter of the patient.

OP No.: every time the patient gets an OP consultation at a hospital, a unique OP number for the facility will given to the patient for that encounter. This OP number will be the same for any immediate follow ups recommended, usually within 2 weeks. 

You can think of every hospital maintaining 3 separate registers- 
1. patient registry (MRD No.)
2. IP registry and
3. OP Registry

Current need:

Since CARE is adopted only by smaller hospitals, they may have a more simplified approach to patient registries. What we gather is that hospitals may not be keeping separate OP registers but only patient registry (MRD No.) and IP registry. Hence currently, we can retain the existing fields in CARE for IP and OP numbers and allow users to type in the MRD No. within the OP field if the hospital does not have a separate OP Numbering system.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#7748
activity.text:
#7686 renames "Dcotor's Notes" to "Discussion notes"

Discussion notes to have 2 threads of Chat. 
1. Doctor's Discussion
2. Nurses Discussion

May be contained in 2 tabs within the chat window. 

- Nurses and doctors both must be allowed to post messages on both chat threads. this may be needed in the following scenarios
1) Doctor through TeleICU notices that the patient's Oxygen mask is not fitting properly. The doctors will be leaving a message for the nurses in the Nurses Discussion thread instructing them to correct it. 
2) In the doctor's discussion thread, the doctors are discussing the patient's condition and the remote doctor may have raised a question regarding a particular symptom the patient has. The nurse may be able to quickly respond to it and provide the doctors with a quick answer. 

Therefore, even though it is important to differentiate the 2 threads, doctors and nurses both may participate in these chats.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#7343
activity.text:
@vishisht-dubey 

The message that you suggested would be great when a Local doctor is trying to reach a doctor at the hub.

However, the Doctor Connect feature allows communication between different stakeholders. For eg:
- Local doctor to hub doctor
- Hub doctor to local doctor
- Hub doctor to the local nurse
- local nurse to the local doctor

So we need a message that holds good in all these above scenarios. A simple message like the one below works well for all.
"Dr/ms/mr <name of doctor/nurse>

I have a query regarding a patient.

< link to patient file >"

Keeping the above scenarios in mind, can you see how to improve the message?

2) The feature to allow WhatsApp routing when the user clicks on the card was introduced after studying user patterns. Doctors generally prefer using communication over WhatsApp. Especially when using CARE on phones, it's very difficult to click precisely on the icon. So allowing users to click anywhere in the card makes it easier. My recommendation is we leave it as is.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#6432
activity.text:
@gigincg @rithviknishad @GokulramGHV 

Why I insist on having "start dose and target dose" and NOT min dose and max dose is because :

Titration is of 2 kinds. Up-titration and down-titration. Up-titration is when medicine dosage is slowly increased, and down-titration is when patient is being veined off a medication. In the former, the user is moving dosage from min to max, while in the later the reverse. Hence for users indicating dosage as Min and max may be confusing.

To know more on Drug Titration, you may refer to the scientific paper; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7967860/

We need to Map medicines using the content.

Then we need to connect the medicine search field in prescription module with Medibase database.

The user must be able to not just search for medicine, but also type in a content in medicine and all medication with that content must come up in suggestion.

Eg: When user types in "Paracetamol" in search, dropdown must not only show the generic Paracetamol Tab etc, but also branded medicine like "Dolo 300mg", "Dolo 650mg" etc. (the main content of Dolo is paracetamol)

activity.text:
This is expected behaviour. 

Discharged patients must show up for sure. 

LIVE patients are also shown in the list because otherwise, if one hospital in CARE is not updating patient data properly, and have kept the patient LIVE in CARE even after the patient may have left the hospital, no other hospital will be able to access the patient card later.

Since we authenticate with DOB, the process should work fine

War- time will have only 2 difference from peace time configuration.

1) 1 additional feature of shifting approval authority (control room) approval. Keeping that as the first steps further simplifies the flow. In peace-time configuration, the flow will start from step two. 

2) the destination approval can be done in peace mode by anyone. In war mode, it needs to be restricted to staff from destination hospital or shifting approval authority. 

If we can have these two setting coded in such a way that is easily switchable, that would be ideal

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#5271
activity.text:
**Relevance of "recommend discharge"**
The reason we have an option to Note "Recommend Discharge" in log update and then a separate "Discharge from CARE" option is because in most cases, the Treating physician would clear the patient for discharge, but the actual discharge may only happen after one of multiple of the following events are done:
1) The patient is on an infusion (medication given through drip) and the doctors may have asked nurse to wait 2-3 hours for drip to complete before sending the patient
2) The patients bill may need to be settled
3) The patient insurance claim process maybe ongoing
etc. 

Therefore the actual discharge (noted in CARE through "discharge from CARE" on patient dashboard) may only be done hours after the treating physician recommends discharge. 

**To-Do**

- [ ] Design a flag for "recommended Discharge" to be visible on the patient list and patient dashboard. the design may be kept consistent with the design for "Action". refer to #5272 . or better the design of actions may be reimagined keeping this use-case also in mind.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#5246
activity.text:
The items to be added to the discharge summary:

- [ ] Date of onset of symptoms
- [ ] Weight and Height 
- [ ] Provisional Diagnosis
- [ ] Diagnosis
- [ ] ONLY if the patient is COVID positive, the discharge summary should have COVID Disease status and vaccination details.
- [ ] PRN Presciption along with normal prescription
- [ ] Health status at admission (History of present illness), Ongoing medication at admission (Ongoing medication) 
- [ ] Allergies
- [ ] Blood group
- [ ] Discharge details- Discharge reason, Discharge prescription, Discharge PRN Prescription and discharge notes
- [ ] Hide Care Patient ID
- [ ] Status during consultation
- [ ] Procedure
- [ ] When any of the fields have no data, DO NOT show the field in discharge summary


Leaving out some info because:
- Category- since the categorization is loosely based on 4 categories without any clinical definition. It is only a tool used internally and does not have much clinical relevance outside. 
- Consultation history need not be detailed out in the discharge summary 

EDIT THE FORMAT OF THE DISCHARGE SUMMARY FOR INFORMATION TO APPEAR IN THE FOLLOWING ORDER
___________________
**Hospital Name
Patient Discharge Summary**

Name of Patient :                                                        Gender:                                              Sex:
Age:                                                                              DOB:                                                  Blood Group:
Address:                                                                       Ph. No.      

**Admission Details** (as a heading)
Status during consultation:
Date of Admission:                                                     IP No:       
Symptoms at admission: along with date of onset of symptoms  
Medication history (commorbidities)
Health status at admission (History of present illness)                                                    

**Treatment Summary** (as a heading)
Prov Diagnosis:
Diagnosis:
If COVID Disease status is positive, then show COVID Disease status, COVID Test result Date: COVID Vaccination details.
Prescription (Table)
PRN Prescription (Table)
Investigations conducted (table)
Procedure: 

**Discharge Details** (as a heading)
Date of Discharge:                                               Discharge Reason:
Discharge prescription (table)
Discharge PRN prescription (table)
Discharge Note: 

Treating physician (verified by in consultation form)

activity.text:
Clarification on the Issue:

**How the Review Feature should work:**
- The user must be able to set a review time in the consultation/edit consultation form. Or later on in a log update form.
- Once the review time is set, then within that time if a Log Update is not filed for the patient, then the "Review Missed" Badge must appear on the patient card.
- When a log update is filed for the patient, the preselected review time must come pre-filled in the 'review after' field in log update.
- With every log update filed, the review clock must reset.
- If the user, the the log update doesnt edit the 'review after' field, the same interval will continue for review, with the review call resetting with every log update.

Eg: I file a 1 hr review in consultation form. I file a log update in half an hr. The log update form will come prefilled with 1hr in review after field. I can choose to edit it to 2 hrs. Then once i save the log update, the clock for review must reset. If no logupdate is filed in another 2 hrs, the "review missed" label must appear on the patient grid in patient list. Then once i file a log update, the clock must be reset again with whatever time is mentioned for review in the latest log update.

**Issues in CARE now - to be resolved**

- [ ] When I select a review after time in consultation form, and later open the edit consultation form, I see the review after field as blank. I must be able to see the review time i had set previously and also have the option to edit it.
- [ ] When i edit the consultation form to add/edit review time, such time must be considered from the time I edited the consultation, and not the time the original consultation was filed.
- [ ] When a review is missed, an a "review Missed" flag appears on patient card, the flag must dissappear once I file a log update. 
- [ ] The log update form must come pre-filled with the previoud review time set (either on the consultation form, or on the previous log update)- the user must have option to edit it. 
- [ ] The "review missed" flag must come right below the patients name on the patient dashboard as well (https://care.coronasafe.in/facility/7ab27974-32c8-4e36-bdf9-dbf102524718/patient/cc52390c-ac8a-4af5-9806-f3df7ee1795a/consultation/7037609e-3c25-45ed-bfd8-e01c346cbd45)

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#370
activity.text:
Let's have a feature to list facilities in any hospital.  

Add a field for "Services available" and give a dropdown with the Multi-select option.

A few options must be 
- CT Scan
- Maternity care
- X-Ray facility
- Neonatal care
- Operation theater

This information must be visible as small flags below phone. no. on hospital dashboard (https://care.coronasafe.in/facility/551f9e09-04a3-4f52-ade2-1db45588741d) as well as on facilities list (https://care.coronasafe.in/facility)

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care#850
activity.text:
Multiple people can be assigned to the same bed.

Eg: https://care.coronasafe.in/facility/015ad911-39b7-4104-b304-bf8178c33830/patients
2 patients are assigned to Bed10- 10bedicu.

Add rule that if a bed is occupied by any patient, that bed must not appear as an option in the dropdown in "Assign bed" window.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#2016
activity.text: The "Diagnosis" field must be a text field. This text field must allow the user to type and search through any disease in ICD-11 (Internal Classification of diseases available at https://icd.who.int/en . The user must be able to find the right disease and select it. We need to also have an "Others" option here for when the user is not sure about the ICD category. The other option must allow the user the type and enter any text.
